Reviews.Title: Best laptop among the similar alternatives
Reviews.Author: Philip J. Warburton
Reviews.Content: This would probably be 2-3 stars if there were anything else comparable, but since there isn't, I'll have to give credit just for making a cheap laptop without Windows available at all. The nice things about it are the decent screen (finally a cheap laptop with better than 1024x600 resolution, so at least all my applications will fit on the screen) and the SD card port which holds the card flush with the case (This being the main thing I hated about the Chromebook).If you want to compare it to a Chromebook, this wins by far, but it will take just a little bit of effort to make it better in every way. Namely, installing pipelight to get Netflix and Flash working properly, and fixing the trackpad sensitivity. The pipelight installation has been addressed in other reviews here, but it's worth pointing out that pipelight can also be used to install the Windows Flash which may work better than the Linux one which has fallen behind. However, I haven't seen any mention of how to fix the trackpad. If you google for "fingerhigh fingerlow" you should find instructions to fix that.That said, it's obvious that this is a Windows laptop running Ubuntu, and that not much thought was put into it. On the positive side of this, everything can be made to work great with a little bit of effort.

Reviews.Title: Great laptop !!!
Reviews.Author: Lai
Reviews.Content: I got this for my husband while he's in school and he loves it !!! He can do all his homework on it and most of his classes are online.

Reviews.Title: Hardware okay, but the installes Ubuntu is just too heavy!
Reviews.Author: Matthias Sedlmeier
Reviews.Content: The main problem with this device is it's operating system. The installed Ubuntu is just too heavy, especially when it comes to Unity. I've installed Xubuntu, an Ubuntu which uses another desktop (XFCE instead of Unity). Now it runs at least 5 times faster and you are really able to work with it.The Netbook itself seems okay. In this case the installed Ubuntu is the problem. Buy it and install an Debian 7 oder XUbuntu. It's nearly impossible to run Ubuntu with Unity / GNOME on it, because it is sloooooooooooooooooooow.Have fun.

Reviews.Title: Installing Windows 7 and finding drivers - information!
Reviews.Author: vdb
Reviews.Content: First of all this notebook is a nice piece of hardware, nothing too special but it does what it should do.If you're looking for specs and pros and cons look at the other reviews, they are pretty good.I'll be explaining how to get Windows 7 working on this machine and where to find correct drivers.I don't use dual boot and have no experience with it, so I can't help you, I just have Windows 7 on this machine and nothing else.Everything was tested by me, so everything should work perfectly, but having said that, I'm not taking any responsibility for what you do.If you're cool with that, let us continue.Installing Windows 7 is pretty straight forward process, you don't have to "hack" anything or whatever else, setup is as normal as anywhere else.I'd like to point out that Windows 7 32(x86) can be installed but I couldn't find all the drivers that I needed, so that is a no go.Windows 7 64 is what I had to install in the end.Bare in mind that if I could choose I would never go with 64bit Windows on this machine, there's just 2 gigs of ram so a 32bit Windows should work better.But even with 64bit I'm happy, no issues whatsoever.I installed my Windows 7 64 from a usb, I'm pretty sure you can use an external optical drive too.During the setup you'll see that there's some lack of space on your hdd that you can't account for, that space is reserved for Ubuntu and Windows setup can't detect that partition, but after you have installed Windows you'll be able to delete it and use that space too.By deleting that partition you won't have Ubuntu on your hdd anymore.While I was in setup I deleted all partitions that could be detected and made a primary partition for installing Windows, afterwards it was business as usual.When the installation is finished you'll have Windows 7 64 installed on your notebook but without any drivers.I found all of the needed drivers on Asus website, tested them out and after getting everything I needed I did some additional tests to see if everything was stable.As of now I have zero problems, so you should be good too.These drivers can be downloaded from Asus 1015E-DS03 support page for Windows 8 (they will work since they're made for Windows 7 too:[...]Realtek Audio Driver  Version  V6.0.1.6839ATKACPI driver and hotkey-related utilities  Version  V1.0.0027These drivers were a bit more tricky to get, but it's easy for you now, select Windows 7 64bit from the dropdown list and then find the one which is below the link:[...]Alcor Multi-Card Reader Driver  Version  V3.4.117.01527[...]Intel INF Update Driver  Version  V9.4.0.1016[...]Intel Rapid Storage Technology driver  Version  V12.5.0.1066[...]Athros LAN Driver  Version  V2.0.15.16[...]Intel Management Engine Interface  Version  V8.1.0.1281[...]Intel USB3.0 Driver  Version  V1.0.7.248[...]Intel Graphics Driver  Version  V9.17.10.2963.01[...]Broadcom Wireless Lan Driver and Application  Version  V5.100.82.143You should be good to go at this point with all of the needed drivers covered.Like I said, I have tested these (and some others) and they are stable, but you can always try others if you feel like it.If you need any applications they can be found too, when on one of the above links, click on change your model -> Notebook -> Apps and then check out all that you need.I think I have covered everything important, if you have any questions let me know, and I'll try to answer them.Hope this little tutorial will help you out.Have a wonderful day!---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Update 10/08/2013Two things:As Michael Maiorana pointed out, you might have some problems with the video driver (I never had any issues whatsoever), updating Windows 7 to sp1 should help out with this issue. (Thank you Michael Maiorana)While on the same subject, updating Windows 7 with the latest updates will help you out regarding system resources and the notebook will run better under updated Windows 7. (You can find different websites which show that updates do help out!)---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Reviews.Title: fast little pc
Reviews.Author: george morris
Reviews.Content: works great very easy to use very fast like it beeter then windows the linex connects to internet fast and easy

Reviews.Title: Solid little laptop - open your mind and give Linux a try!
Reviews.Author: Sparky
Reviews.Content: For $229 this little laptop is great. As long as you know what you are buying and do not expect MacBook Air build quality and you at least have an idea of what Linux is and aren't hopelessly computer illiterate, you will probably like it as much as I do. It's the last of a dying breed, a teeny, tiny 10" netbook, which is great for those of us who love this form factor. It has a 1366x768 screen, which is as high res as the $5-600 "budget" laptops with 14-15" screens. One important note on the screen though. It looks like a screen from a $229 laptop because, well it is. That cost it a star from me. The screen is OK, but you will not want to use it for hours at a time, it will exhaust your eyes. The colors are washed out too. Like I said, it's perfectly serviceable, but if you're even a little picky about screen quality, look elsewhere, this is a super cheap TN panel that just gets the job done. The 1.1 Celeron processor is no barn burner, but it will run circles around any of the old Atom or AMD netbooks you may have used before. The hard drive is generous enough at 320 gb and 2 GB of RAM is more than enough for Ubuntu to run well. Note: The trackpad isn't great, as many others have said, but it's tolerable for me. Out of the box this machine is ready to use even for a newbie. Don't be afraid of Linux. What you have here is a clean, attractive, quick OS which will NEVER get a virus or malware and never grind to a crawl the way any Windows computer that isn't meticulously maintained will. As long as you have basic requirements, like surfing the web, music, email and maybe some light gaming, this tiny laptop will serve you well. I'd be comfortable giving one to my Mac using mom. If you come at it with a little sense of adventure and the willingness to try something new and you will find that Ubuntu is a delightful alternative to Windows and there's a nice selection of great, FREE apps to fill most all your needs and you can try them all out without any fear of breaking your computer or downloading some virus/malware/worm that's going to steal your identity. What's more is you get a nice $70 discount by not having to pay for a Windows license. I installed the LXDE desktop environment to make things run a little leaner than with Unity, if you're a little Linux-savvy you'll know what that means and you might give it a try too, if not, no worries it's not a necessary modification at all.

Reviews.Title: Very Fast Shipping
Reviews.Author: arcturish
Reviews.Content: I ordered this for my son for school. As I was explaining all the rules to him for using internet, it was already here. It is light and small enough for him to put in his backpack to take with him if he needs it.He loves the webcam it has so he can talk to his friends online and the sleek look.I love it..:)Houston, TX.

Reviews.Title: Apparent Keyboard Failure
Reviews.Author: Korrigan
Reviews.Content: I wanted to like this computer and I did for just about a month before the keyboard failed.Since it's a column of keys I'm guessing it's the keyboard matrix that has failed. It has all the hallmarks of a hardware failure since an external USB keyboard works fine.I really did like this computer once I got used to the funky touchpad mouse. I also put a fair amount of time into getting it all configured just right.I'm hoping Amazon will issue a full refund. Since the price has gone up I doubt I'll try again since I've had two out of two ASUS computers now have problems with keys and the mouse is funky.It's really disappointing. I was hoping this was going to be the ticket and it would have been had the hardware quality been better.Is it fair to give it one star when any high volume product can experience failures? I think so given that I still haven't heard from ASUS and it's a huge PITA no matter how this problem is resolved because this was my main computer and is in active daily use. Even a new replacement will require the duplication of many hours of work getting it set up.Not only that but the price is such that it's not throw away but it's also not worth putting a lot of hours into. It's right on that frustrating threshold where you want a replacement but don't want to put more time into configuring a new one.  All in all it's a really poor customer experience and I seriously doubt I would ever chance purchasing another ASUS product because of it. What if they really do have quality issues and this isn't just a one off failure? I don't want to learn that stuff the hard way.A prompt response from ASUS to resolve this and I wouldn't have posted the review until afterwards and presuming a favorable outcome would have put it at three stars.

Reviews.Title: Dusty/Overheating no way to access and clean out!
Reviews.Author: matt schmitt
Reviews.Content: I purchased this machine 4 months ago.  This machine has to be one of the poorest constructed machines I have ever purchased.  It only has one tiny little slot for the PCU fan (which clogs with dust) and has no way to open and dust it out.  Now the fan is completely inoperable and the machine overheats  and shuts down within about 20 minutes.

Reviews.Title: Nice!
Reviews.Author: Gwen Ellison "Stacey"
Reviews.Content: I was on the internet before Windows came out. I have tried a Mac, been using Windows for a long time. I got really tired of my computer crashing and constantly having to remove malware, viruses and so on. It seems like you have to spend most of your time keeping that junk off your computer.I've heard Ubuntu is a lot more stable and you don't have to spend a ton of time keeping your computer virus-free. Well, I got my computer yesterday with Ubuntu pre-installed. I am not familiar at all with Ubuntu. I set up my computer, got familiar with it and then I updated it. I was worried because a lot of people lost access to their wifi as it was updating.  I hard-wired it to the internet and updated. It took a while , an hour or so. Then everything is working great. I am used to updating something on Windows and something doesn't download correctly and your stuck. When you update just keep it charging and hook up to ethernet and there shouldn't be any problems.I love it!!! I never had any problems at all. I already had a small  ASUS laptop so it was almost like using the same computer. The touch-pad was a bit different but I had no problems at all. I think I am going to like Ubuntu.

Reviews.Title: Very nice
Reviews.Author: Jeremy
Reviews.Content: Exactly what i needed high quality lasts forever on full charge very comfortable keyboard small storage space doesn't over heat :P

Reviews.Title: Great Laptop for the price
Reviews.Author: Zak
Reviews.Content: The laptop works really well and offers everything that it said it would. But, make sure to keep in mind that you sometimes might not be able to open up a power point on a computer that runs on an older software. That is the only downfall  I have experienced. Other than that, it is very portable, sleek, and gets the job done.

Reviews.Title: Mediocre, as expected
Reviews.Author: Colton
Reviews.Content: The good:-Cheap-Small/Lightweight-Good battery life-CHEAP.The bad:-Poor trackpad (Use a mouse)-Not powerful whatsoever (I've crashed my browser multiple times just trying to load more than one tab at a time)-And my biggest complaint (and why I decided to write a review) is the charger for it. After about a month of use, now the charger will suddenly stop charging, and I have to jiggle the connection between it and the computer, and pray it keeps working for more than 30 seconds at a time. You know it's bad when I have to actively monitor my battery so I don't shut off WHILE it's plugged in. I'm not sure whether it's the charger that isn't working right, or the jack/port/whatever on my computer, but it doesn't really matter which it is.Overall, I would recommend it if you're looking for something small and cheap like I wasUPDATE: I sent it in to get the power issue fixed. I got it back, and now about 1 week later the display is having some serious problems if there is light pressure on the display, front or back (screen turning white for no reason, freezing sometimes, other issues that are hard to describe). Dropping this down to two stars, it's more trouble than it's worth

Reviews.Title: Overall great! Unbeatable price for this little one. Just need a little effort on our side & is ready to go :)
Reviews.Author: Lawrence
Reviews.Content: I've seen complains that Ubuntu is not working for one or another :)... and this put the rating down to 4 stars?  Come on! 99% of us put Windows 8 or Windows 7 on them & works wonderful. This is a cheaper version and is suppose to involve a little work on our end to be up and ready... a format & a 20 minutes install. Otherwize, if you are lazy, the complete version with W8 is with $100 more expensive.Personally I love it!

Reviews.Title: Great performance at a great price
Reviews.Author: Nick Ballard
Reviews.Content: The 1015E with Ubuntu is the perfect combination of mobility and performance. Its 1366x768 display is on par with larger and more expensive laptops, and the 320GB hard drive is more than sufficient for everyday computing tasks. One thing to keep in mind is that the drive is non-upgradeable, at least without a lot of hassle. The included Ubuntu 12.04 LTS operating system performs reliably and makes efficient use of screen real estate. There is a slight delay when launching applications, but it isn't so much of a delay as to affect usability. The built-in webcam is nice and sharp, making for a pleasant videoconferencing experience. Although Skype is not installed by default, it was relatively simple to install from the included software repositories. All in all, I would highly recommend this purchase to anyone looking for an affordable general-purpose notebook.

Reviews.Title: Great device, great price!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Perfect for a kid who wants to learn more about computing than the usual MS/Apple path.  My son loves it!  He is getting ready for college next year, and this is more of a techie minded device than your normal run of the mill laptop.

Reviews.Title: More versatile than a tablet and smaller than a regular laptop.
Reviews.Author: Joe O. Marcom "fan of the Undead"
Reviews.Content: Almost identical in size to the Eee netbook, and lacking a DVD drive, calling this a "laptop" is a slight exaggeration. However, screen size is usable, keyboard feels "right" and the mousepad is - - a mousepad.  An external drive or flash drive will work in lieu of the DVD, if one is needed.  Set-up was a snap, and the wireless LAN connects instantly to whatever access point you choose.  Unless you MUST have a Windows-only program such as MS Office or Turbotax, Ubuntu is the preferred choice and easy to use.  I know, because I have an Asus laptop which dual-boots either Ubuntu or Windows 7 and I very rarely use the latter.  You will find that almost any Windows program you can buy has a Linux counterpart, which you can download and install at no cost by using either the Ubuntu Software Center or Synaptic package manager.

Reviews.Title: Thanks for a Ubuntu laptop.
Reviews.Author: Rolf
Reviews.Content: This ASUS network came with Ubuntu, my favorite OS, and functions very well, and has something you don't see very often today, a removable battery. For the money one pays it is a wonderful purchase. Rolf.

Reviews.Title: Very nice for Linux users.
Reviews.Author: BooBoo "BooBoo"
Reviews.Content: Bought for a relative,this arrived in 3 days flat with free shipping.He loves it being a linux pro,re formatted to how he likes it (changed to Unity setup from Ubuntu),added crypto,etc etc.Said he had no difficulty with wireless internet connection working after change but that may just be because he loaded from another working setup he had,I dont know but A-OK for him in that regard.This is a fast little machine,trading files via sd card,this machine 3 times faster than a 10 year old desktop with 16 of RAM,really amazed me.Only con he says is its hard to remove the SD card,maybe experience will improve that?Oh,and like everyone else he uses a wireless mouse.We also watched videos from a 12 foot HDMI thin cable to a plasma TV,picture and sound were GREAT.Anyhow,for you linux folks,he flat out loves the computer.We paid 239.99 delivered.-----------------Edit 5/29/14-Has performed flawlessly,BIL thrilled with it.

Reviews.Title: Good for the price, just be aware of what Operating System you want before you order
Reviews.Author: M. Perkins
Reviews.Content: I bought this Laptop for a friend.  She needed an inexpensive, basic laptop to do light work on.  Upon receiving this laptop I removed the slow mechanical drive and replaced it with a 120 GB solid state drive I had laying around.  Being that my friend isn't too tech savy I installed Windows 7 on it(this comes with Linux), though I have no qualms about using Ubuntu myself(at least for basic needs as I am too heavily vested in Windows to ever make the switch to either Linux or Mac).

Reviews.Title: Great Laptop for the price
Reviews.Author: Glenn Farmer
Reviews.Content: Excellent Laptop (Notebook) for the money.  Ubuntu really should be the wave of the future if it wasn't suppressed by the other big players of non-Linux operating systems.  Expand your horizons and ditch proprietary operating systems such as Windows or Apple.

Reviews.Title: I like my ASUS it works for me. It's larger althouh i have to zoom in a lot so i can see.
Reviews.Author: karen stinnette
Reviews.Content: I like it. I believe it will satisfy what i need to do. I like the fact of having the zoom in option. It's fast enough and it was affordable.

Reviews.Title: First experience with ASUS and Ubuntu
Reviews.Author: Garland
Reviews.Content: Great value and overall an excellent machine with good battery life.  Very fast with a nice display.  Touch pad is less than ideal as reported by other reviewers (reason for 4 rather than 5 stars).  OS is significantly different from Windows but is not difficult to adjust to.

Reviews.Title: great little laptop
Reviews.Author: g
Reviews.Content: this was a gift and the person loves it, small and portable. may purchase the 11.6 inch in near future.

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: Karan
Reviews.Content: This is the Second time I purchased the same Model.Its Great and Compact Laptop for the Price asked for

Reviews.Title: Improved over previous netbooks, but still issues
Reviews.Author: Ian
Reviews.Content: This product is essentially an improved netbook. Better resolution, no atom cpu.This is what the netbook should have been. If you had a netbook and liked it (or had a netbook that was 'almost good enough'), you will like this product. No surprises. This is the shell of a 2010 netbook updated with more recent hardware.PROS:Battery lifeNo M$, no bloatwareIntel celeron CPU is much, much better than atom.Excellent netbook, precisely what I expected and was looking for.CONS:Touchpad is worse than older models. Use a mouse.Integrated memory. Not user expandible. 2GB is 2GB. This is the reason for 4 stars.Like all asus netbooks, replacing the HDD with an SSD WILL involve voiding your warrentee.Like all asus netbooks, case is held together by fragile plastic clips. Be aware of this if attempting to disassemble. Clips are located in same places as previous asus netbooks.NOTE:If considering the version of this product with windows, get this model instead, wipe the hard drive, and reinstall windows. This will avoid the bloatware and save some money.

Reviews.Title: Asus 1015E-dS03 10.1 Laptop Ubuntu OS
Reviews.Author: wmdshooter
Reviews.Content: I like this little netbook. it is easy to travel around with and always handy. I am familiar with Ubuntu and see it as a definite plus. The only drawback is as others have said the mouse pad is not so good, but it is usable.

Reviews.Title: Excellent laptop for the money
Reviews.Author: Kimomaru
Reviews.Content: For about 250 dollars, this machine is a good purchase in my opinion.  I bought it because I wanted something more than a tablet but more nimble than a laptop, and this form factor fits the bill.  I also needed to be able to install a Linux distro on it since I have absolutely no interest in Microsoft, Apple, or Google OSs.  When I read that this laptop comes installed with Ubuntu, I felt pretty confident that it would fit my requirements.  I do recommend a few things;1) Install your own OS before doing any work on it.  I've found that a brand new Ubuntu 13.10 install with the online searches and search plugins removed and disabled will be MUCH faster than the default install that comes on the laptop.  If you must use Ubuntu, then reinstall it.  I reinstalled this morning and am typing this review on it right now - the laptop performs admirably.2) I would have preferred Debian as my OS on this machine but found that the Broadcom drivers available for it have trouble connecting to hidden SSIDs.  I will most certainly be installing Debian on this laptop if this issue is ever sorted out.  Some folks might not mind spending a few hours working through a wireless driver issue.  Ubuntu seems to work perfectly straight away after install.For techies looking for a linux solution, this package is perfect for me.

Reviews.Title: Small Laptop that is worth every penny!
Reviews.Author: Fisher
Reviews.Content: I have both this Ubuntu and a small Chromebook. They both complete the same task I need, which is using the internet on the go without having to carry my full laptop. I carry it on airplanes and meetings (especially at restaurants where you do not have much space).The Ubuntu can do much more than a Chromebook (which is basically Google Chrome, Google Docs, and any aps you find). The Ubuntu comes with its own open source productivity suite (similar to Microsoft Office). I have created basic spreadsheets using this software and had no problems. I was able to open my spreadsheet in Excel when I got back into the office.The Keyboard is one of the better ones I have used on a 10 inch laptop with larger keys, but I do accidentally hit multiple keys at once when typing.Overall I am happy with the purchase and I loved the price!

Reviews.Title: Very much as expected: a better-than-netbook mini laptop
Reviews.Author: OEJ
Reviews.Content: This machine came with Ubuntu 12.04. I use Ubuntu by choice on my other machines, so I'm at ease with the operating system provided.With a Celeron processor and 2 GB of memory, don't expect this little laptop to be a powerhouse ultra-book. You CANNOT upgrade the memory, incidentally; on most (all, according to ASUS) of these motherboards the memory is soldered on. It has a 320-GB hard drive. However, similarly-priced netbooks typically have a slower (Atom) processor, 1 GB of RAM, and a smaller solid-state hard drive; this machine is a cut above.Ubuntu booted and ran out of the box. I added a wireless mouse (worked with no configuration needed) and a LE brand external DVD writer (again, Ubuntu recognized the hardware and no configuration was needed). I added an extra app dock (Cairo-dock) and a Gnome-style application menu (ClassicMenu Indicator) to supplement the Unity interface. The installation of Ubuntu came with most applications pre-installed, but of course I added a few of my own favorites as well. (For Windows users: Ubuntu has an official application repository, and programs found there are malware-free. Programs from outside the repository can be loaded as well; all the ones I've loaded are clean as well. In general, the Linux universe has far fewer adware/trojan/malware dangers than Windows. Edit -- nearly all the applications are free for the downloading.)Software: you get Firefox, an office suite, email and messaging programs; a number of system utilities, photo managing and image editing software, a couple of music players, CD/DVD burning software (though you have to get an external optical drive), movie player, sound recorder, and some other stuff. All apps are fully functional; there are no demo or time-limited trial apps here.Many other reviewers have noted the difficulty in hitting the right-side "shift" key; I have the same problem. But, looking at the keyboard layout, I can't really see how ASUS could have done it much differently without altering the modern QWERTY layout. ASUS has pushed the keyboard out nearly to the edge of the chassis, and I think it's about as good as you're going to get for this form factor. I read that the trackpad is difficult to use as well, but as I planned on replacing it with the wireless mouse that wasn't important to me.Sound is predictably tinny. None of the laptops I've used have good sound; again, I don't think the manufacturers can be blamed. It's hard to imagine how to get full-spectrum audio out of speakers wedged into a thin, flat, non-resonant plastic case.Note that on this ASUS the audio jack is a combined headphone/microphone jack: you'll need an adapter that splits the 3-contact pin to one 2-contact headphone socket and one mono microphone socket. They're readily available.The screen is sharp and clear. Viewing angle is just average. Color balance is good.I've run a couple of other Linux-family operating systems on the ASUS, using USB installations: Puppy Linux and -- the most interesting -- a port of Android to x86. For the latter I had to use the Ice Cream Sandwich version, 4.0, because the newer ports wouldn't boot. For the small screen, Android x86 makes a pretty sensible OS for light web browsing even though the ASUS has no touchscreen and you have to use mouse gestures instead.To boot from USB on the ASUS 1015e you insert the media before bootup, and then click "esc" repeatedly as the machine boots. If an OS is detected on USB then you'll get a menu offering the option to boot from media or from the hard drive.The Ubuntu operating system could present a learning curve for exclusive Windows or Mac users, but Linux has come a long way from the days when you had to be a terminal-code guru just to install a network card. All the hardware on all my systems has been recognized and installed seamlessly. And of course, Linux does not have the pervasive virus-and-malware problem that afflicts Windows.So far I've been using the ASUS 1015e for a couple of months, and I'm very pleased -- ESPECIALLY because I don't have to lug around my 6-lb Toshiba anymore!

Reviews.Title: Asus 1015E UBUNTU
Reviews.Author: Jeff Hirschfeld
Reviews.Content: I bought two of these for our SOHO locations, to use as an isolated work station for online banking only, no web surfing no email. Linux for virus free, spyware free, key-logger free secure online banking.  I also installed a white-list  so they can not go to unwanted web sites.  That being said, let's get on to the review.PROS: They are absolutely great!  and Asus tech support is also great.  I could not get a wired ethernet connection during the set up.  It was my fault because of something I did during the initial boot up and drivers install.  Asus tech support answered the phone right away, no hold, and got it up and running in minutes!Asus computers come with a restore partition.  Remember that if you are going to repartition it.  It allows you to completely restore the machine to factory just like it was out of the box.  Great feature!CONS: The touch pad is useless! Forget it. You need to get a mouse.  It recognizes MS mouse no problem. Also there is no indicator for CAPS LOCK.  How could they miss that?  You have take the whole machine apart to get to the hard drive and the memory is soldered in, so it is really a "use it to it's death and then throw it away" machine, like a smart phone.The con's are not too bad and pros greatly outweigh them.  I would highly reccomend this unit.

Reviews.Title: Very affordable
Reviews.Author: helen malubay
Reviews.Content: The unit was very good and with the price, I considered it BEST BUY!I wonder why there was no official receipt included in the unit like that of Sony viao which I bought together with Asus.The unit was pretty cute.  The wifi detection was fast.  Ubuntu was user friendly.I recommend this for students writing their research papers

Reviews.Title: I love it!!!
Reviews.Author: Kyros Nox
Reviews.Content: I love this notebook, and my lady loves it too. I like the double finger scrolling instead of the scroll bar at the side.

Reviews.Title: Works as expected, and you can install a different OS if you want.
Reviews.Author: Cristina
Reviews.Content: Works as expected, good price, and you can install another operating system if you want. I'm happy with it. I have had it for a couple months now.

Reviews.Title: Great netbook!
Reviews.Author: Ashley
Reviews.Content: I love it. The keybored feels very sleek and is easy to use. It has tons of space on it and i love that it is a linix netbook. It stays chraged for up to 8 hours. Great purchase!

Reviews.Title: The computer is great but the Ubuntu OS does'nt like to accept some programs
Reviews.Author: Franklin Warfel
Reviews.Content: I chose the laptop for the size and did'nt want windows OS I wanted to be in control of my applations.

Reviews.Title: Linux is a great system, this netbook harware comes up short
Reviews.Author: william s
Reviews.Content: cons:  non glare screen, why use high resolution only to make it fuzzy with a no glare screen?... headphone and microphone are the same jack...no blue tooth...hard to use track pad...key board is sub-par, those of use using two fingers will be hard pressed to see the symbols on the shift elements of the keys...the right shift key is half size...wall wart is underpowered, takes a long time to charge battery, much longer if netbook is in use...adaptor plug on end of wall wart easily falls out of the netbook receptacle at the slightest bump...Ubuntu Unity is a poor choice for this netbook, install Kubuntu and use the folder view on the desktop(Xubuntu might be an option too)...battery life is not as long as it should be.Positives:  not all bad- the device is 64 bit and pretty snappy...wifi works well...one usb 3.0 plug two 2.0 plugs...keyboard has great touch...Kubuntu works great

Reviews.Title: Boy is it small
Reviews.Author: BadOldBear
Reviews.Content: I am a novice, but have not had any problems with Ubuntu. It sure beats Vista or Windows 8 as to performance.

Reviews.Title: It was okay, but not great.
Reviews.Author: Jenie Wilcoxen
Reviews.Content: Ended up giving it to my father-in-law because I was unable to use it for most of my school assignments.

Reviews.Title: It's Umbeauty
Reviews.Author: MissAnnThrope
Reviews.Content: I am so glad they made this available. Can't really get much use out of tablets. Need a keyboard, HD and "full laptop features." These netbooks are now powerful enough to use as proper computers, so long as you keep it reasonable (no gaming, no CAD, no Avid, etc.).The keyboard is pure genius, if you don't have big hands. I have medium hands and it's almost too small. Yet I can touch type at normal speed after a warm-up. It also feels solid. Keys are whisper smooth. Very nice job there.Used it as a workstation. Can't get the display to work right on my 23 inch monitor. Everything is Wiiiiiiide, and streeetched out. Can't fix that. Doesn't really hurt my flow, and bad comedies are somehow funnier with the distorted faces. Bonus.Linux is a lot friendlier than it used to be, and the WP is a good one. I set up my normal work and only saw computer code once. Not as weightless as old Limux, but still a heck of a lot lighter, faster, less annoying than recent Windows bloat-a-sauruses.True on some of the negatives reported. It does run a bit hot. idles cool, but full run with streaming video, multiple browser pages and word processing got me a steady 82 degrees. Now use chiller pad. Ambient temps made a huge difference. Cooling system is responsive, but throughput is inadequate. Needs another 2 mm of space in there, I reckon.Also, charge takes a long time, and the charger (while beautifully small and light) is cheap. I don't doubt that some folks have broken it. Battery life not nearly as good as advertised, but still a lot better than a lot of devices. I get maybe 4 hours, which isn't bad considering the power of this little guy.Brain flatulence: Would it have killed you, Asus, to have upgradeable RAM? Really, now, maybe $1.50 a unit? If it's a space problem, make it 2 mm wider and kill two birds with one stone (cooling and RAM slots). Oh, and the shiny black plastic on the cover is tacky. The matte finish elsewhere on the machine is very nice, though. Shiny bits make it seem cheaper than it really is.Otherwise, awesome computer and a great value. The CPU is as fast as my old Athlon X2 desktop grunt machine with 2gb RAM. Maybe even faster. Woohooo.

Reviews.Title: Good for lightweight use
Reviews.Author: Keith W Trnka
Reviews.Content: I'm taking a Coursera class with a friend and wanted something cheap to program Octave while I'm over his house.  It's cheap and portable.  Plus I wanted to try Linux again.  It gets the job done for Google Apps, Dropbox, Octave, Git, etc.The good:-Cheap.-Pretty good battery life.-Wakes up from sleep quickly.-Pretty lightweight.-Ubuntu is nice once you start to get used to it.The bad:-Like many reviews mention, the touchpad is flaky.  I'm used to it now.-The right shift key is really tiny, so I keep hitting up arrow by accident, then adding code in the wrong place.-If you unexpectedly find that you need to use more heavyweight applications (in my case, Android Studio), you'll find that it's pretty slow.  If you're patient it's not too bad; only occasionally it got bad when java seemed to churn on building my code.-The screen is kinda bad, but I'm spoiled by the wonderful displays on phones and tablets.-I accidentally updated my wireless driver and that broke wireless, which was a scary experience on Linux.  Luckily some googling and an ethernet cable fixed it.Edit (1-2 months later):-I've had a number of people say "oooh Ubuntu" followed by "ewww Unity".  I'm not used to Gnome or KDE so it's not an issue for me.-I'm mostly used to the touchpad but sometimes it gets very jittery or very slow.-I'm used to Android Studio on this now.  The slowness varies a lot by the size of the project but it's been acceptable for small projects.-While running on battery it still powers the USB ports.  So when I'm doing Android development on battery, it's charging my phone.  I'm not sure that it's a bad feature, but you'll find that the battery drains quickly in this situation.-The wifi drop-down menu is weird.  It's sorting alphabetically rather than by signal strength, so the wifi in your house might not be in the top 5 or so in the quick list and you may need the larger menu.

Reviews.Title: very nice
Reviews.Author: Jay
Reviews.Content: Its is very nice and very clean I was most impressed with its quality you just need to make sure you have the right operating system

Reviews.Title: Great to carry around
Reviews.Author: Michael
Reviews.Content: Very nice for a netbook.  The HDMI-out is my favorite feature!Slow with Visual Studio, but can handle a browser and a program like Eclipse or Project at the same time.

Reviews.Title: Good except for touchpad
Reviews.Author: Josef735151
Reviews.Content: This is exactly what I wanted in terms of how light it is and how long the battery lasts.  I can use it intermittently all day long at school without worrying about charging it, and it's light in my backpack.  It's less than half the weight of my Dell laptop and the battery lasts more than twice as long.I don't like the version of Linux that came installed so I installed Xubuntu, which works great for me.  I tried Mint, which I have got to work with a Broadcom wireless chip once on the Dell, but with school going on I don't have time to try to figure that out again.  With Xubuntu, the wireless worked with no problem.  I did need to download the ISO for Xubuntu and I used UNetBootin to install it to a USB drive (it took > 2 GB).  This is necessary because there is no disc drive.  If you're going to want to do anything fancy -- multimedia presentations, use a TV tuner, or even attach your own printer to it -- I can't guarantee Xubuntu will work.  The Ubuntu that comes preinstalled is more likely to work, especially after you update it, but I don't really like the desktop, customization, or the shell.  You could do a dual-install and have 2 versions on there but your safest bet for multimedia is Windows, or Mac if you use that.  The laptop will do things like play YouTube videos and stream music on Myspace, though.Typing is pretty easy, even with my somewhat large hands.  The only downside is the touchpad.  It is the worst touchpad I've ever used.  It's workable but such a pain.  I changed the settings to disable it while I'm typing so the cursor doesn't jump all over the screen when my palm touches it.  When I absolutely need it, it works but it's hard to pinpoint things, hard to click and drag, and on Xubuntu the right-click doesn't work (although there is a context menu key, which I miss on my Dell :) ).  I live with it because most of what I do on there is typing notes for class or programming.  But if you can't live without Eclipse (I avoid Eclipse anyway), you'll need a mouse because Eclipse makes you use the mouse all the time.All in all, this is a good laptop if you're on a budget and just want it for simple things like writing papers, email and Youtube, scripting, etc.  Not the Cadillac of laptops but it's been really helpful in college.

Reviews.Title: Ubuntu Lives On
Reviews.Author: shutterbug "shutterbug2"
Reviews.Content: My son is a hardcore Ubuntu user. Ever since he crashed (3) Windows XP desktops due to viruses and malware, he has never looked back once he switched to Ubuntu back in the 8th grade in middle school.He is now a college student in civil engineering and almost religiously continue to use Ubuntu as his operating system since it comes with the basic office suite that works incredibly well.It is about time that Asus reintroduced the netbook especially powered with the Ubuntu operating system. Tablets are OK for entertaining.  However, when you need to travel light and get some serious work done, a netbook especially with Ubuntu is the most cost effective and efficient platform to get real work done.He still has his old Acer Aspire One netbook which continues to work well with Windows XP and Microsoft Office.  However, this machine is definitely continues this fine tradition of excellence and efficiency with a much more stable and faster operating system. And of course, there is a lot of other great software that is free. Definitely something you should consider.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Mighty Minnie!
Reviews.Author: J. M WILINSKY
Reviews.Content: I wanted a powerful laptop that was very portable. This is the perfect one. It is the only tiny laptop with a full size(for a small laptop) hard drive and dual core processor. I chose one with the Ubuntu OS for four reasons: it lowers the price by a considerable percentage since it is open-source; it is less likely to require virus software; it should run a bit faster than Windows 8(I do love Windows 8 on my desktop!); and I wanted an adventure! I am thrilled with the quality of the device and how well it functions. I have no problem attaching devices, such as a mouse or optical drive, and I love the keyboard and the trackpad. When you pick this device up, you can feel that it is very solid.As far as Ubuntu goes, I like it very much. The software center is amazing, including thousands of free(and some at cost) downloads that are Ubuntu compatible. That, by the way, is the key to success with Ubuntu: Do things "the Ubuntu way"! A lot of software will not run on Ubuntu, but plenty will. Don't try to download directly from the internet. If it is not in the software center, the only reason is that it is not compatible. For example, Skype that comes from the software center has a different look from the Windows version. In addition, as a scientist, I was very impressed by all of the technical software, much of which I have never even heard of, available. In fact, some software actually runs better on Ubuntu than on Windows 8! For example, I cannot get Eclipse(for Java programming) to run on Windows 8 and to install it requires unzipping files and so forth. With Ubuntu, Eclipse installs with one click and works well. Freemat also runs better on Ubuntu(on Windows 8, in Freemat evoking "help" causes the program to shut down).To make sure you have no problems using this, be sure to allow it to update, which is especially important when you first set it up. If you are not familiar with Ubuntu(and if you are reading this, you probably aren't), it may be difficult to notice when it is asking to update. You will see the update manager trying to get your attention on the left side of the screen in the launcher. Two tiny arrows surround the icon and it flashes a bit. You click on it and a screen will appear which will be self-explanatory. You may also click on the top icon to get the desktop(the "dash" in Ubuntu) which allows you to search for applications. Just type in "update" and the update manager icon will appear on the desktop for you to click on. You should also do this from time to time.Is this a good laptop for a first-time computer user? Probably not, since fewer people are around to help with Ubuntu. For those who are somewhat familiar with personal computing, this is a great choice.

Reviews.Title: UPDATED for Opensuse 13.1 [Was Good so far (OpenSuse 12.3 + SSD)]
Reviews.Author: Andrew Cooke
Reviews.Content: Update: Opensuse 13.1 installs fine (wifi and screen brightness work out of the box), providing (1) you select the UEFI option when you boot from the DVD for the first time and (2) you add "kernel-firmware" to the installed list of software (on the page just before install runs, where you can review options, select "Software" and then add it via Yast).I have been really impressed with the power of this little machine (I'm a software developer and have even run virtual machines on it), but the trackpad is terrible - it's much better with an external mouse.-----------This arrived today (my partner returned home after visiting  the US - they don't seem to deliver to Chile).Changing the disk for an SSD (you need a slim 7mm one) is surprisingly tricky.  It's *not* intended to be user-serviceable.  There are a couple of videos on YouTube that show how (search for ASUS 1015 disassembly) and there's no need for fancy tools, but you have to force a lot of plastic tabs, some worryingly hard, and open / close various ribbon cables (of the "no plug, just printed wires" type).But having said that, it all worked.Installing OpenSuse 12.3 worked fine - the installer automatically did the correct boot type (UEFI or whatever it is).However, once booted up, the network card did not work.  It seemed to be auto-detecting / loading a b43 module, but that lacked firmware.  Searching for that I found a script to install the firmware (download to a connected machine and copy across on USB stick), but that didn't help.  More searching and it turns out that the chip I have (BCM4313 acording to lspci) needs the brcm module.  So I blacklisted b43 and rebooted.  That turned out to need different firmware, which is described at [...] - I cloned the git repo ond copied across the brcm directory.  And that worked!  It's currently updating to the latest packages over the net.So, in summary, install of OpenSuse 12.3 on SSD works OK, with a little footwork.  So far it seems like a decent little machine for the price (no backlit keyboard, or light, unfortunately).

Reviews.Title: Pretty Cool Stuff
Reviews.Author: Magic Shopping Network
Reviews.Content: For $200 this is pretty cool.  I got the linux version.  I'll review both the computer and Ubuntu.  Ubuntu is essentially what feels like a windows clone.  I haven't tried using linux since about 2002 and the improvements are stupendous!  No problems downloading software or going online, I was online wireless almost immediately I can download software via a little app called "software center" and printing was no problem at all, I just plugged in and started printing...LINUX you've come a looong way, this used to be a nightmare in earlier versions.  The only thing which sucks about Ubuntu is you need to use this crappy program "Gimp" because Adobe Photoshop makes no version for linux.  But I think Ubuntu is pretty easy to use and in some ways even easier to use than windows.  It feels exactly like windows but just a little clunky here and there in superficial ways which are not a problem really once you get used to it.  The fact that the software is all free and the price is lower totally justifies this though and I'm ok with it.  Ubuntu is quite customizable but requires a week or two, maybe even three or four weeks, learning curve.The hardware part is problematic though.  The keyboard is tiny and annoying you will have typos but you get used to it after about three weeks and it becomes less and less of a problem with time.  Battery life is not so amazing here though.  It sort of feels like the computer only lasts about 3 - 4 hours and takes about 2 hours to fully recharge...which can be annoying.  I bought this computer so I can practice networking and learn Ubuntu.  It's perfect for my needs.  The sound and keyboard isn't set up on arrival, I set it up myself though without a problem.This computer has a few minor hiccups but for $200 it's definitely pretty awesome.  I can watch movies at night study Ubuntu and just have fun knowing this is open source software I got it for cheap and it's kind of mysterious and fun.  One star is knocked off because there were some problems, but they are minor and mostly hardware related.

Reviews.Title: Cute Compueter But Small
Reviews.Author: E.W. in Chicago, IL
Reviews.Content: This is a cute computer, but small.  When I try to hit the shift key, I end up hitting an arrow key.  If you want a small laptop with a small screen, then this one is a good buy.  It has software like writing, database, spreadsheets, where other laptops don't, and you have to buy them.  Consider carefully if you want to purchase a small laptop with a small screen and small keys.

Reviews.Title: Decent netbook, could be much better
Reviews.Author: Victor Leonard
Reviews.Content: The good:  good netbook that is physically small and light with great battery life and a higher resolution display than most netbooks.Less than good:  It really should have more than 2 GB of ram and it suffers for it unless you install an SSD or similar.  Installing an SSD is overly complicated (but doable, having proper tools like a spudger makes a huge difference) and voids your warranty.  This is sold with linux on it.  The linux drivers for both the wired ethernet (Atheros AR8162) and wifi (Broadcom BCM4313) chipsets are still not settled and if you upgrade to a new linux distro or even just to a newer version of ubuntu (it comes with 12.04 and 13.04 is current when I purchased this) it will not work without jumping through lots of hoops.I am very happily running mine with a 250GB SSD and lubuntu (a light weight distribution of ubuntu).  With SSD and display not set at full brightness I get 6-7 hours of run time from a fully charged battery depending on what I'm doing.

Reviews.Title: good warranty, design, portability, quickness, and cheaper since your buying the operating system Ubuntu not pricey Windows OS
Reviews.Author: realjb
Reviews.Content: I bought mine as refurbished. It is probably the best laptop with warranty at that price. It has the less expensive Ubuntu operating system. ASUS gives a 1 yr warranty and I have sent it back and  yet it may still need to be sent back, because some of the functions with the mouse pad seem to not always function. The drawback is the fact it doesn't have a mouse pad that has separate keys to each side of the pad, for the right/ left mouse click. So, I use a mouse with it, since that is easier.  OUT OF THE BOX YOU NEED TO KNOW 1ST, HOW TO MAGNIFY THE SCREEN- AND THAT IS A FUNCTION THAT MY PREVIOUS WINDOWS xp ON HP-MINI DIDN'T HAVE EXCEPT AS A PRESET THAT KEPT THE SCREEN ALWAYS ENLARGED.** HOW TO: (pressing Cntrl. & rolling the mouse roller- which will change the size of the screen) just when using those keys, not a preset. For the money the hardware is very good since it has the ports i want- and it is less expensive due to the Ubuntu experience that unties you from constant fees for Microsoft windows operating system. If you are dedicated to learning ubuntu and will fiddle around enough to get the functions from the software that you want. AND DON'T MIND USING THE WARRANTY TO GET THE BUGS OUT. WORTH THE MONEY TO ME.

Reviews.Title: Great netbook with Ubuntu
Reviews.Author: W. L Powell
Reviews.Content: This is a great Ubuntu netbook.  I use it for travel when my System76 Serval Professional is too heavy.  Solid battery life (I have achieved 8 hours with use that does not push it too hard).  If you have never used Linux, this may not be the machine for you.  There will be a bit of a learning curve.  That said, Ubuntu is very easy to use if you give it a chance.  I am glad I gave this laptop a chance.  It had proven to be perfect for me travel needs that don't involve high end number crunching.  I save that for my office workstation and my heavy desktop-replacement System76.  If you are a linux user who travels, give it a chance!

Reviews.Title: Loved it
Reviews.Author: Young
Reviews.Content: This was a gift to my mom. She loved it!!! So happy to make my mother happy with her laptop!

Reviews.Title: Ubuntu is mostly fine for what I want to do with two exceptions
Reviews.Author: Robert
Reviews.Content: I'm mostly happy with this netbook. We chose it because it had more power for the price since it runs Linux Ubuntu instead of Windows. I already have a Linux Mint partition on my two desktops and thought everything would be fine. All works well except that no one had been able to help me configure the system to use VPN to access my office computer remotely. I can work around this issue, but I would not buy a Linux computer again for this reason. I use the netbook when I travel with carry on luggage because of its small size and light weight but still use my full-sized laptop for car trips.I also had to send the netbook back for warranty services when it wouldn't boot shortly after I purchased it. On the plus side, the ASUS service was wonderful in comparison with the other vendors that I've had to deal with. (The only computer that I've ever  bought that didn't need warranty service was a reconditioned one.) The service person didn't give me a hard time about needing to service the netbook. The document included with the returned fixed netbook said that ASUS had to reinstall the operating system.

Reviews.Title: Excellent!
Reviews.Author: Jose Escobedo Del Cid "jopez"
Reviews.Content: I bought this small laptop so I could use it on the train and transports. It is faster than what I expected. Of course, I only run basic stuff, but things like the browser and video work fast.Before I bought a linux-based tablet (for the same purposes), but it wasn't a good investment. This laptop works better.I'm happy with this product.

Reviews.Title: Works great for many tasks
Reviews.Author: David Zalewski "After-hours science reader"
Reviews.Content: Of course, Windows is still required for some applications, but if you know enough or have enough time, you can figure out how to do it with this machine.  Quiet, reliable, great price.

Reviews.Title: ASUS 10.1 inch laptop
Reviews.Author: Carol A. Shell "Carol S."
Reviews.Content: It is a good little computer for the price but does not include windows and have been unable to hook printer to it.  I had been used to computers that did more when transcribed.

Reviews.Title: excellent product
Reviews.Author: Ever
Reviews.Content: excellent product for the price this is very good sign is super fast Buy 2 and it went really well I am very happy with this price

Reviews.Title: Great Linux Laptop!
Reviews.Author: Kenny Stier
Reviews.Content: Best laptop I've ever had. It's made for Ubuntu (my operating system of choice since 2012). Great laptop for the price! The hard drive is formatted badly, though. (Recommend a fresh install of the upcoming 14.04).

Reviews.Title: mini powerhouse
Reviews.Author: Sugananth
Reviews.Content: Excellent config & speed,  it's a mini powerhouse. Great performance and ease of use, I was impressed very much. Overall very good.

Reviews.Title: A fine little laptop
Reviews.Author: Doug Roberts
Reviews.Content: It's a sad commentary to the lack of education / sophistication of many of the reviewers here who complained that this laptop did not come with Windows.It's not supposed to come with Windows, it comes with Ubuntu Linux pre-installed.  That's a feature.  I'd pay extra to not have Windows on it.Given that, I prefer Linux Mint to Ubuntu, so that's what I installed. Mint 16 installed in about 8 minutes, no muss no fuss, and everything just works.  With the 1.1 GHz Celeron processor, it's fairly speedy as well, and streaming movies from Hulu work fine full-screen with no stutter.This is a great little laptop, and a great value.

Reviews.Title: Touchpad almost unusable
Reviews.Author: Eric Warren
Reviews.Content: I bought this to replace my Asus eeePc that I owned for several years.  That computer was excellent - long battery life, worked well and had plenty of computing power for what I used it for.  This one works fairly well, however the battery life is considerably shorter and I've had more problems with it.  I am a fairly novice Ubuntu user, but am familiar.  When the computer arrived, I immediately updated to the latest version of Ubuntu, which took a couple of days to get through.  When I was done, the computer did not suspend (still doesn't) and the touchpad was very touchy (jumps every time I go to click by tapping the touchpad - usually resulting in clicking on the wrong thing).  I contacted Asus support - they were fairly quick to respond, but the only advice they could give me (for both of these problems) was to reinstall the operating system (reverting to the one that came installed).  Since I had considerable time invested in updating this, I wasn't so inclined...  Since others have had the same experience with the touchpad, I am led to believe that it is not a software issue.  I am using a mouse with the computer when practical, other times it is enough of an annoyance to make me wish I had shelled out more for a better computer, but not enough to make me give it up yet.I did have the screen fail on me (not sure what happened) and I sent the laptop off to Asus for repair - they were quick to respond, repair and send it back to me in good working order.  There customer service seems to be quite good in general.

Reviews.Title: hard to figure out
Reviews.Author: Theresa
Reviews.Content: can't get the hmdi on it to work , thought I would be able to look at movies off my commuter, didn't come with instructions.

Reviews.Title: does alright
Reviews.Author: William A. Broderick
Reviews.Content: I bought this when Microsoft introduced Windows 8.  So many people were fussing about it.  I was unable at that time to pay the Apple tax.  Now that some time has passed I concluded that all the fuss about 8 was for naught.  Wish I had purchased a surface with detachable keyboard.  There was so much controversy at the time and I needed a computer immediately.  The device is adequate and gets the job done.  However Linux is a pain and I feel like I am using something that is 10 years out of date.  Not much of a better device than my wife's Kindle, and hers certainly does much better at streaming video.

Reviews.Title: Runs Fedora 20
Reviews.Author: A user
Reviews.Content: After receiving the netbook, I booted fedora 20 on it off a bootable usb disk. It ran pretty slow off the usb disk but after installing fedora to the hard drive (overwriting all previous partitions) I found fedora 20 to run flawlessly. It seems a little slow after signing in and moving the mouse to the top left to open the gnome3 menu, but later attempts of reproducing returned no results.The wifi works great and the battery life is decent as well. (up to six hours with a dimly lit screen) The CPU runs at around 5-8% on idle with firefox running. It will play youtube and flash videos in full screen without any issues in full HD. The volume and screen dimmer keyes on the keyboard work out of the box, but will require the fn key to be pressed.My only complaint is that the trackpad has integrated buttons and I cannot double tap to click. The keyboard takes a little getting used to, but works well with the exception that the home and end keys are now secondary and require fn to be pressed as well.Pros:Runs Fedora 20 FlawlesslyRuns Kali Linux off a bootable usb drive without issuesDecent battery life ~ 6hrs with dimmest settingCons:Touchpad has integrated buttons and is loudfan is noisy and left half of netbook runs hotHarddrive is slow (5600rpm) - Plan on replacing this with an SSD (Samsung Electronics 840 EVO-Series 250GB 2.5-Inch SATA III Single Unit Version Internal Solid State Drive MZ-7TE250BW )Runs pretty hotFeels cheapFan is loudWhat works with Fedora 20:Just about everything!WifiHDMIKeyboard volume / screen brightness controlsUntested:webcam

Reviews.Title: Love It!
Reviews.Author: T. Murphy
Reviews.Content: Got this for my 12 year old daughter for Christmas... haven't seen her since...Very compact, great speed and worth the money.

Reviews.Title: excellent product I recommend it widely
Reviews.Author: Julio Solorzano
Reviews.Content: excellent product I recommend it widely that covered the expectations required that my daughter actually think of buying another thanks for such a good product

Reviews.Title: Good netbook
Reviews.Author: rsr72
Reviews.Content: Linux user for years.  Ubuntu is very easy to use.  First netbook.  Would buy again.  Runs a little hot.  Feels a touch cheap, but for less than 300, I guess maybe overly picky.  Just nitpicking about case.  An 11 inch netbook might be ideal.

Reviews.Title: Not what I expected
Reviews.Author: Beth
Reviews.Content: I had thought I had ordered the touch screen version but that is not what I received. It is good for a younger person. Still a lot of features I have not accessed.

Reviews.Title: Great price
Reviews.Author: Juan Carlos
Reviews.Content: I bought ther laptop with the Linux OS installed in it. It is a good little laptop, but the mousepad is HORRIBLE. I uninstalled ubuntu and went with Linux mint. I did not have any issues with wifi card, card reader or anything like that, so that was a plus. Make sure you get a mouse, because you will get very frustrated with the mousepad

Reviews.Title: Smaller than I realized,
Reviews.Author: Rachel Haueter
Reviews.Content: but my daughter likes it and says the smaller size is more convenient for transporting. Works well screen is sharp.

Reviews.Title: Very Goog, Muy Buena (Venezuela)
Reviews.Author: Nestor Morales
Reviews.Content: Muy buena para su precio economico..Excelentes caracteristicasLo unico que viene con linux pero se le puede montar windows 8, o el sevenVery good for its affordable price ..excellent featuresThe only thing that comes with linux but you can mount windows 8, or seven

Reviews.Title: Exactly what I needed!
Reviews.Author: Jim
Reviews.Content: I bought this just so that I could have a super portable GNU/Linux machine that I could take anywhere. I needed something that I could use to do schoolwork that had an actual keyboard (in other words, not a tablet) and long battery life. This laptop is exactly what it says. It gets about 6 1/2 hours of battery life on the internet and is super light and small. Ubuntu runs pretty well on the hardware and I haven't really noticed any huge performance issues so far.The only two drawbacks that are apparent so far are the track pad and the right side of the keyboard. The track pad is just too sensitive while typing. I have wider hands so I always seem to move the pointer when typing (even though I have the sensitivity turned all the way down and have the "turn off track pad when typing" enabled). The right side of the keyboard is quite cramped. The right shift key is particularly bothersome as it is way to close to keys that I normally use it with and as a touch typist I find myself taking my right hand off my home row a little to often.Other than these rather nit-picky design issues this little machine is one heck of a bargain. And don't worry if your no computer geek. Ubuntu is a "gateway" GNU/Linux distribution, so you should be fine! Highly recommend this if you need a affordable, small, portable alternative to a tablet, Chromebook, or some other laptop that claims ultra book status but is way too expensive for what you get and is still kinda too big to carry around with disappointingly similar battery life.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Linux Notebook Computer
Reviews.Author: Caffeinator "Caffeinator"
Reviews.Content: I have 3 kids. I want them to use the computers in our house, but I don't want them to spend hours and hours on gaming web sites or youtube, sites which they invariably visit the moment I turn my back. I had an idea: buy a cheap linux notebook and use it as a router.When I bought this notebook it was $210. I also bought a USB ethernet adapter. I am a long time linux user (20 years), a long time Fedora user (since Fedora Core 5), and had zero experience with Ubuntu. It was not hard to figure out. I was able to set up this computer as a router between my wireless and my Comcast router (don't forget about proxy ARP!). It was trivially easy to install and set up a DHCP server. It was easy to configure the computer to stay on all the time, even with the lid closed. Everything works perfectly.My next task is to configure unbound to only resolve certain websites, and also to use crontab to automatically alter iptables at certain times of the day (so that my kids can't get out of bed at midnight and start surfing the net). I am very happy with my purchase, and am waiting for the price to come back down so I can buy another of this model.

Reviews.Title: This should be your next small platform laptop!
Reviews.Author: Russell
Reviews.Content: Ubuntu. What more is there to say. I purchased this for my teenage daughter. After explaining the design of Ubuntu and the differences between it and Windows and OS X, she loves it.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for teen
Reviews.Author: Courtney
Reviews.Content: Got this computer as a christmas gift for my teen who absolutely loves it. Had a hard time figuring out the system at first but think we have finally figured it out. Makes homework time much easier now that we don't have to share one computer.

Reviews.Title: Perfect gift =)
Reviews.Author: Melissa Kini
Reviews.Content: I bought this item for my daughter as a Christmas gift and I'm very pleased with this purchase.  It's the perfect size and is very user friendly, my daughter is also very pleased with this product and that's what matters the most to me.

Reviews.Title: Jumpy Trackpad Very Frustrating
Reviews.Author: Ana Logue
Reviews.Content: I've owned this for about 3 months. The single most frustrating problem for me is the bad Trackpad. It looses control and the cursor jumps around with no warning or the cursor does not respond, It causes endless trouble every time the computer is used, slowing every action down as I try to coax the cursor to the right spot.Other problems are well discussed in other reviews, bit the bad trackpad makes everyday use of this PC constantly annoying.

Reviews.Title: Loving it
Reviews.Author: Thomas Schei
Reviews.Content: I really enjoy this netbook. I love that it has Ubuntu. I've wanted to get off of Windows for years, but never liked OSX. The only thing that is annoying is the touchpad is way too sensitive (and yes have gone into the system settings to attempt to reduce the sensitivity).

Reviews.Title: Ubuntu rejects Key Ring password.
Reviews.Author: Ronald K. Forsmo
Reviews.Content: During set-up, I chose a password (and immediately wrote it down) for the Key ring, and now Ubuntu rejects it.  Huh?  Their help menu or site isn't very good, so I'm stuck by-passing that aspect.  I'd be happy to re-install the operating system anew, but reluctant to do so without advice.  Any suggestions? Other than that, it's pretty sweet.

Reviews.Title: not bad 4 $$$
Reviews.Author: farmerizzy
Reviews.Content: seems to be all its advertised to be.takes a while to get acclimated to ubuntu op. system otherwise it would have been 5 stars. audio is sort of lame. nbd though.

Reviews.Title: You get what you pay for
Reviews.Author: Thiago V. Marzagao
Reviews.Content: I'm satisfied. I was looking for a second laptop, something I could SSH into from my primary laptop, upload some Python code to it and leave that code running, thus keeping my primary laptop available for other tasks (writing code, email, etc). This Asus gets the job done. Yes, it's not a powerful machine, but at that price it's as powerful as they come and sufficient to run the scripts I have. The small keyboard and screen can be a bit uncomfortable, but I use the machine mostly through SSH, so keyboard and screen size is rarely an issue for me.

Reviews.Title: Excellent modern netbook
Reviews.Author: Mikemo
Reviews.Content: I'm writing this review on the Asus 1015E. Unlike my first netbook, the Asus 701, this keyboard is big enough to be comfortable and I have little trouble touch typing on it. I was originally looking at a chromebook for web surfing and checking email. When I saw this I had to try it. The display is excellent and is anti-glare coated, which I appreciate. The resolution is great for web browsing, unlike the 701 which was much too small.If you are looking for an Internet "appliance", this will work fine. The Linux build is solid and sets up easily. One negative is that you won't be able to watch netflix on this easily. There are some work-arounds, but they can be complex. It does everything else I need as a "google" appliance. But it is capable of much more. There is an incredible amount of free linux software available. You just have to look around.The laptop doesn't seem to get very hot at all with just normal browsing. If you tax the processors more it will run hotter (and use more battery). The fan is quiet and not objectionable.Just for fun, I tried installing windows 7 x64 on this machine but was never able to get the video drivers to load without a bluescreen. I went back to the Linux build. If anyone figures out how to do this I'd love to hear how you did it.I took off a star for the touchpad. It is useable, but not great. The buttons are integrated into the pad itself toward the bottom. If I leave my left index finger just resting on the pad above the left button, I lose control of the cursor. A minor annoyance, but something I noticed. I also dinged it for not having upgradable ram or an easily upgradable hard drive. I understand the size constraint, but thought I would mention it. However, 300GB of hard disk and 2GB of ram is likely plenty for this machine and what I will use it for.Overall an excellent buy, and of course sent by Amazon quickly and on time.Update:I figured out the windows 7 problem. The Intel HD video drivers would cause a bluescreen on reboot. Before installing the drivers, I installed Service Pack 1 into Windows 7. After installing Service Pack 1, the Intel HD drivers installed without any problems. There is a review a few up from mine that lists all the drivers to install and how to get them.

Reviews.Title: A good computer for the price, just some negative details.
Reviews.Author: rober58
Reviews.Content: It is overall a good computer.The only bad thing is that the trackpad may be unresponsive.And the processor is a little under today's standards.

Reviews.Title: Great!
Reviews.Author: Joan St. Johb
Reviews.Content: Great gift for my son who is a college freshmen. This is his go to laptop. He absolutely loves it!

Reviews.Title: Perfect for student
Reviews.Author: Jon R. Brito "ANGRY COLLEGE STUDENT"
Reviews.Content: I am a Electronic/Computer engineering major and this is perfect. Small enough that when I go to class or travel it isnʻt cumbersome, yet powerful enough for me to complete my programming homework on. Great battery life. I also loved that Ubuntu came pre-installed on this bad boy. Overall would HIGHLY recommend!

Reviews.Title: Functions well.
Reviews.Author: Charles Nelson
Reviews.Content: Does a good job out of box, but if you are looking to do more than regular or simple computing uses around the house, you might want to go with something different. Nice to use, able to do more than tablet.

Reviews.Title: Great buy
Reviews.Author: Gene J.
Reviews.Content: Bought this as a replacement for my aging ASUS 1005. Like this one sooo much more. Better screen resolution, nicer keyboard and I love Ubuntu! It runs fast, no slowdowns or freeze ups. I reccoment this one as a sure bet!

Reviews.Title: laptop is great.
Reviews.Author: millie
Reviews.Content: I bought this asus1015E-DS03 10.1-inch laptop for a friend on his birthday he loves it.He needs one where he can take with him every where so i surprise him with one.It is is good working condition and i love it.

Reviews.Title: it was ripped open
Reviews.Author: Joseph C Bishop
Reviews.Content: came with no charger, and i couldnt turn it on. So i bought a charger,l how would you have guessed? it didnt turn on. piece of crap.

Reviews.Title: Booted 3 times, black screen on the fourth. Returned it.
Reviews.Author: EES
Reviews.Content: This was my second attempt to use Ubuntu. First, a year ago, I had borrowed a friend's CD that had come from an Ubuntu magazine, and first tried to load Ubuntu, and then I think Xbuntu, without success, onto a Thinkpad.Purchased this machine. It booted 3 times, freezing each time after attempting some task. First, tried to download system updates. Freeze and crash. Tried to get onto the net with the pre-installed Firefox. Freeze and crash. The fourth time, the startup chime went off, but the screen was black. I guess this was my last attempt this this OS.For reference, I don't consider myself to be a computer geek, but I am not opposed to a certain amount of tinkering. But this machine just seems to require tinkering beyond my desire. I can FTP and telnet (showing my age), and for some reason like doing things like dialing up a modem with my Mac Plus, and with the shell access that my particularly cool ISP gives me, using telnet to check my email with it. I like networking machines and playing games. So, I have a passing understanding of the command line. But it's not enough to get Ubuntu to work, apparently. I'm stumped and out of patience.

Reviews.Title: Notebook
Reviews.Author: VB+6
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my daughter who is hard on laptops. I LOVE ASUS and the company I have ordered from 3x before. I'm not sure about the Ubuntu OS yet, since it is a gift.

Reviews.Title: Hit and miss
Reviews.Author: Paula
Reviews.Content: First unit we had died pretty much within hours, and the track pad and buttons didn't feel like they were in place right.  Had no problems swapping it out with Amazon and the second unit has been performing satisfactorily.The unit we bought came with Ubuntu,  Beware that the Broadcom wireless driver is difficult to configure under any other Linux OS than what it came with, even other version of Ubuntu and you cant download the Linux drivers from Asus so you have to go and get reference drivers. We tried several flavors of Linux as the partitioning scheme that showed up on the laptop was not what we wanted, and included a FAT partition as well as Linux one, which might cause a user to think there was less disk space than actually available depending on where you typically store files.Windows 8.1 runs nice and stable on the system, and detects the wireless properly.Graphics are not powerful enough to run most modern games, but it does run minecraft well enough.Overall its decent, and you get what you pay for in terms of quality control, as this is the lowest price laptop we cloud find anywhere.

Reviews.Title: it just arrived
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "travel photo"
Reviews.Content: Just turned it on and I see an account set up.  No documentation is provided and I am feeling ripped off. It looks like I paid for new and got used.

Reviews.Title: Very Good Performance
Reviews.Author: Johnny Rangel
Reviews.Content: I recommend this laptop but with Microsoft Windows 8.1. The use few days with the Ubuntu system, other days with Microsoft Windows 7 and I really do not give the desired performance. So I recommend installing MS Win 8.1 on it. For the rest, I liked the performance of this laptop.

Reviews.Title: Defec
Reviews.Author: Choua X.
Reviews.Content: Everything about this product is great EXCEPT for the fact that the headphone jack does not work. Perhaps it was only me who got  defect.

Reviews.Title: Not so good
Reviews.Author: Bothered
Reviews.Content: Bought so my granddaughter could do homework at my house. It is so slow and clumsy it frustrates both of us.

Reviews.Title: Ubuntu?
Reviews.Author: BS Webb
Reviews.Content: Nice computer, but if I had known what 'Ubuntu' was before purchasing I would have opted for a different computer.

Reviews.Title: She loves it
Reviews.Author: Kathrine
Reviews.Content: We bought this as a birthday gift for my fiance's 14 year old sister, she loves it. Perfect little netbook :)

Reviews.Title: Recommended
Reviews.Author: L. Wires
Reviews.Content: Great little "learning" laptop. The small drive space and older version of Ubuntu keeps me from giving it a 5 star rating but the OS is easily upgradable and the machine's specs make it very capable. I may be getting a second machine because of its small footprint.

Reviews.Title: Nice tiny laptop (without Windows Tax)!
Reviews.Author: PCS SCHOLTENS
Reviews.Content: This small laptop works out of the box with a long battery life. The Ubuntu installation automatically accept updates from the special ppa archive, so I'm sure the hardware is working to the best effort. Unfortunately it is not delivered by the normal sales channels in Europe, but the AC adapter is capable of running the 240V / 50Hertz too (you only need a mains connector adapter).

Reviews.Title: This is a netbook; They died for a reson.
Reviews.Author: Ryan
Reviews.Content: It sure looked pretty on ubuntu.com!Expect no more than about 4 hours battery life.TN display looks like a TN display. A bad one.The right [Shift] is about half the size it needs to be, so I was always hitting the up arrow instead. I was also mixing up [CTRL] and [Fn] too, due to the size. If you hunt and peck, it'll probably be fine. If you touch type, good luck.I briefly considered a Haswell Chromebook, but the uncertainty of being able to replace "Chrome OS" with a Linux distro turned me off it a bit. I returned this and got a 5x as expensive VAIO Pro 11I knew what I was buying, but managed to convince myself that it'd be OK. It wasn't.

Reviews.Title: Gifts for my school aged kids:
Reviews.Author: Jewels
Reviews.Content: So glad I purchased these for my kids.  Nice little compact unit, great battery life.  Good price. Easy function.  Basically plug n play.

Reviews.Title: Not allowed to open package
Reviews.Author: Kathi Morris
Reviews.Content: I sent this back because If I opened the package I couldn't send it back. Why would I want a product that I couldn't check out first to see if it met my needs.

Reviews.Title: DO NOT BUY
Reviews.Author: Linda
Reviews.Content: After 30 hrs and speaking to 3 techs to get this thing up and running. It was DEAD ON ARRIVAL and the last tech at ASUS told me to send it back immediately. I spoke to a customer service rep from Amazon and he was very gracious and professional. He refunded me the cost immediately.  I sent it back within 3 days.

Reviews.Title: Awesome little computer
Reviews.Author: A. Handford "surfzup"
Reviews.Content: I love this computer. It is fast and Ubuntu is the best operating system ever!! The battery lasts for at least 5hours and this is a powerful little computer with all the function of the big laptops.

Reviews.Title: Do not really care for this product.
Reviews.Author: Erika N. Harris
Reviews.Content: It is not user friendly. Is very difficult to use and has not really served us any purpose at all.

Reviews.Title: Fast  and easy purchase
Reviews.Author: Roselis Franco
Reviews.Content: I  think this puschase  was really fast the way I could get it .It was too easy to get it

Reviews.Title: need a PC but...
Reviews.Author: Nancy Cole
Reviews.Content: returned it, I am not a lap top person.  Besides, the battery was dead when it arrived and I did not realize.  Got this desk top ASUS, good product.

Reviews.Title: Illest s*** i ever wrote
Reviews.Author: anthony
Reviews.Content: this laptop is tuh real deal muh nugz dont even hesitate yuh hurd. even doe my gram ain teh best dont let that speak for this product aha you kna what i mean.

Reviews.Title: Was expecting Windows OS!
Reviews.Author: Vina Rice
Reviews.Content: My husband was purchasing this for my granddaughter who is 5. Did not realize that it wasn't Windows. There is no way she will understand how to use it! She was needing it for school. I will try to return it!  Nice laptop otherwise.

Reviews.Title: Not what I was looking for
Reviews.Author: jona McCollough
Reviews.Content: Was not what I expected,  sent it back for refund.  Was not really user friendly. Went someplace else and got what I was looking for.

Reviews.Title: hate it waste of money
Reviews.Author: Deborah Cross
Reviews.Content: I hate the Ubuntu program it is not user friendly. Also I cant print  from it and thats why I bought it. The printing drivers are terrible. I ended up not using it at all. What a waste of money and I'm retired so every penny counts.

Reviews.Title: this is not a laptop this is a notebook! THEIR IS A DIFFERENCE!
Reviews.Author: melody wood
Reviews.Content: wouldn't recommend to anyone very small! this product was not as discribed! i was very disapointed! i ordered for my sons birthday he was expecting a laptop and this is what came! shame on you amazon!

Reviews.Title: asus
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: It sucks and i didnt like it and it could not do mush as i want it to do so yea it sucks
